newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Hong Kong stocks close down, investors take profits.
newsitem.headline: Hong Kong stocks close down, investors take profits.

text.p: Hong Kong stocks closed lower on Tuesday after a late afternoon slide which brokers described as a short bout of overdue profit-taking.
"This market was long overdue for a short-term correction, said Francis Wong, head of regional sales at DBS Securities.
The Hang Seng Index shed 65.39 points to 12,444.66 after trending sideways on robust volume during the morning session.
Trading was active all day, bringing turnover to HK$7.30 billion, greater than Friday's HK$6.67 billion.
Brokers said they thought selling would be limited.
"While we saw some lock in profits today, locally based funds are not selling because the property market outlook is improving," said Patrick Ho, sales director at UBS Securities.
"They will continue to hold onto their (equity market) positions if they think the property market improvements are going to flow back to the market, Ho said.
Technical analysts are cautious on the short-term outlook.

"In the short term we are running into resistance at 12,600. The market is very overbought and we are likely to see limited upside for the remainder of the week," said Ted Chen, technical analyst at Technical Data Inc.
Chen put minor support at 12,300 points and major support at 11,900.
The property sector managed to fare the best in the afternoon sell-off, while the commercial and industrial sector suffered the heaviest profit-taking.
Swire Pacific dropped HK$1.50 to HK$70.25 and CITIC Pacific lost HK$0.70 to HK$37.00. Both shares were among the most actively traded on Tuesday.
Cathay Pacific eased HK$0.40 to HK$12.20.
Cheung Kong led the property sector, putting on HK$0.25 to HK$62.25. Hopewell added HK$0.15 to HK$5.45.
Banking giant HSBC Holdings put on just HK$0.50 to close at HK$155.50, after trading up to a new record high of HK$156.50.
Subsidiary Hang Seng Bank, hit by profit-taking, declined HK$2.00 to HK$91.00.
